title: Tableau Dashboards
text:
Link to dashboard
A dashboard comparing several employment statistics of fresh graduates from the “Big 3” universities in Singapore (NUS, NTU and SMU) including factors such as employment rate and mean income, across different undergraduate degree programs in the different universities. Data was sourced from the annual Graduate Employment survey from 2013 to 2021 provided by data.gov.sg.

title: Tableau Dashboards
text:
World Happiness Report Dashboard (2024)

Link to dashboard
A visualisation of overall happiness across the world over time using the Cantril Ladder score as a benchmark, in which participants are asked to rank their own lives on a scale of 0 to 10, with 0 being the worst possible lives for them, and 10 being the best possible lives. All the data used in the dashboard was collected from past and current iterations of the World Happiness Report, which aims to review to review and assess the state of happiness in the world using data.

title: Shiny Projects
text:
Link to web app | Code
A web app to identify the financial drivers of profitability among SGX-listed firms using OLS regression and robust econometric techniques. The app analyzes how lagged financial indicators (e.g. debt ratios, margins, asset turnover) affect current profitability (ROA, ROE, etc.), with support for heteroskedasticity-robust errors and regression diagnostics. Users can also filter by industry and financial year-end. Financial data from SGX firms was collected via the yfinance API in a Jupyter Notebook for pre-processing before analysis shown here.

exeRcise book

Link to web app | Code
A simple web application consisting of basic programming questions for beginner programmers to learn both R syntax and programming methodology in R. Based off the exbook package in Python, a package containing basic LeetCode-style practice problems for new coders.

title: The Irreplaceable Role of Auditors: Why Their Expertise Endures
text:
In today’s fast-paced technological landscape, the rise of artificial intelligence and automation has sparked debates about the future of various professions, including auditors. As machines become more advanced, the question arises: Will auditors be replaced by algorithms and AI-driven tools? In this blog post, we will explore why auditors are unlikely to be replaced anytime soon and why their indispensable expertise remains crucial in ensuring trust, transparency, and accuracy in financial reporting.

The Human Touch: Auditors are not merely number-crunching machines. They possess a unique blend of human judgment, intuition, and critical thinking. While automation can streamline repetitive tasks and data analysis, it lacks the context-driven decision-making that auditors bring to the table. Auditors consider business intricacies, industry knowledge, and company-specific risks to offer a comprehensive and nuanced evaluation that goes beyond raw data.
Complex and Dynamic Scenarios: Modern businesses operate in complex and ever-changing environments. Auditors must navigate intricate financial structures, diverse accounting standards, and evolving regulatory landscapes. Their adaptability, problem-solving skills, and ability to interpret non-financial information ensure that audits remain accurate and relevant in a rapidly evolving world.
Non-Financial Factors: Financial statements alone do not provide a holistic picture of an organization. Auditors scrutinize non-financial factors, such as corporate culture, ethical practices, and risk management, to assess an entity’s overall health and compliance. Incorporating these qualitative assessments into an audit requires human judgment and the ability to assess intangible aspects of an organization’s operations.
Relationship Building and Communication: Auditors interact with key stakeholders, including clients, shareholders, and regulators. Their interpersonal skills and effective communication are vital in understanding business operations, building trust, and explaining complex financial matters to various audiences. Human interaction and empathetic communication are hard to replicate through automation.
Fraud Detection and Ethical Considerations: Auditors play a critical role in detecting fraudulent activities and ensuring adherence to ethical standards. Their intuition, experience, and skepticism act as a safeguard against financial malpractices. Ethical judgment and situational awareness are attributes that cannot be programmed into machines.
Evolving Role of Auditors: Rather than being replaced, auditors are evolving to keep pace with technological advancements. They are embracing data analytics, artificial intelligence, and automation to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of audits. Technology serves as a tool to augment auditors’ capabilities, not a substitute for their expertise.

The role of auditors extends far beyond the boundaries of data analysis. Their human expertise, ethical judgment, adaptability, and critical thinking remain invaluable assets in safeguarding financial integrity, corporate governance, and investor confidence. While technology continues to shape the audit profession, auditors are indispensable in ensuring trust, transparency, and accountability in an ever-changing financial landscape. The human touch, combined with the power of technology, will continue to fortify the auditors’ relevance and resilience in the years to come.

title: Structured Query Langauge: Unraveling the language of databases
text:
Structured Query Language (SQL) is a powerful and ubiquitous language that plays a central role in the world of data management and database systems. Whether you are a budding data analyst or an aspiring software developer, understanding SQL is essential for effectively working with relational databases. In this blog post, we will unravel the mysteries of SQL, exploring its purpose, structure, and introducing some of its important commands.

What is SQL? SQL, short for Structured Query Language, is a domain-specific language designed for managing, querying, and manipulating relational databases. It provides a standardized way to interact with databases, making it possible to store, retrieve, update, and delete data efficiently. SQL allows users to define database structures, perform complex data operations, and ensure data integrity, all through concise and powerful commands.
Key SQL Commands:

SELECT: The SELECT statement is one of the most fundamental commands in SQL. It allows you to retrieve data from one or more database tables. You can specify the columns to fetch, apply filters using the WHERE clause, and even perform aggregate functions like SUM, COUNT, AVG, etc.
INSERT: The INSERT statement is used to add new records to a database table. It allows you to specify the table name and the values to be inserted into each column, creating new rows of data.
UPDATE: The UPDATE statement is employed to modify existing records in a database table. You can use the SET clause to update specific columns’ values and use the WHERE clause to filter the rows to be updated.
DELETE: The DELETE statement is used to remove records from a database table. Like the UPDATE statement, it can also be combined with the WHERE clause to selectively delete specific rows.

Creating and Modifying Database Structures:

CREATE TABLE: The CREATE TABLE statement is used to create a new database table. It defines the table’s columns, their data types, and any constraints like primary keys or foreign keys.
ALTER TABLE: The ALTER TABLE statement allows you to modify an existing table’s structure. You can add or drop columns, change data types, or add constraints.

Filtering and Sorting Data:

WHERE: The WHERE clause is used to filter data based on specific conditions. It allows you to retrieve only the records that meet the specified criteria.
ORDER BY: The ORDER BY clause is used to sort the retrieved data in ascending or descending order based on one or more columns.

Syntax Variations:
While SQL serves as the standardized language for interacting with relational databases, it’s important to note that different database management systems may have their own variations in SQL syntax. For example, MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, and Oracle Database, among others, may exhibit subtle differences in how they handle certain SQL commands, data types, and even functions.

These syntax variations may include slight differences in naming conventions, data type handling, date formats, and more. Therefore, when working with different database systems, it’s essential to be aware of these nuances and adapt the SQL queries accordingly.
SQL is the cornerstone of data management, enabling efficient data retrieval, manipulation, and organization within relational databases. By mastering key SQL commands, you can harness the full potential of databases and leverage data-driven insights for decision-making and application development. As you dive deeper into the world of SQL, you’ll unlock endless possibilities to explore, analyze, and extract meaningful information from vast datasets.

See how I turn data into decisions.
I am Teng Suan, a recent Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) graduate from the National University of Singapore (NUS), with a strong interest in business analytics, data engineering, data science, and data-driven consulting.
This website features a selection of my personal projects and includes my CV for download.
If you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects, feel free to contact me.

title: Data Science Notebooks
text:
Code
A deep learning pipeline and model which uses LSTM networks in PyTorch to predict daily stock price direction (up/down) for S&P 500 stocks. The model uses historical price and volume data from the yfinance package, along with engineered technical indicators, and focuses on directional movement to improve stationarity. Performance is determined by classifying price movements accurately using classification tools from sklearn package, and is benchmarked against perfect foresight and random strategies, with detailed discussion on scalability and real-world limitations of using neural networks for trading stocks.

title: Data Science Notebooks
text:
Bank Churn Analysis

Code
A GitHub repository featuring data analysis and predictive modeling for a bank customer churn dataset (from Kaggle) on Jupyter Notebook. The project addresses the business objective of identifying customers likely to churn, enabling targeted retention strategies. The project includes data preprocessing and exploratory data analysis (EDA) performed using pandas, matplotlib, and other Python libraries, with outputs saved for reproducibility. Classification machine learning techniques with sklearn, including model evaluation and hyperparameter tuning, are applied to predict customer churn. All code and outputs are reproducible.

title: Streamlit Projects
text:
Link to web app | Code
An interactive web dashboard which shows detailed insights about users and messages in any Telegram chat group such as user with most messages, when the chat history was most active, etc. Users must have Telegram Desktop installed to use this app. Do note that currently the app is unable to process chat files greater than 200 MB due to resource constraints imposed on the free tier of Streamlit Community Cloud.

title: Streamlit Projects
section: Binomial Options Pricing Model Visualisation and Calculator
text:
Binomial Options Pricing Model Visualisation and Calculator

Link to web app | Code
A web application designed for students studying options pricing, offering an interactive Binomial Options Pricing Model (or CRR Model) tool. It allows users to create and visualize a binomial tree model with custom parameters, export data to Excel and PDF files, and provides detailed explanations of the model’s workings.
